message_1: Let f(z) = 3z - i(z^2 - 3). Find the real and imaginary parts of f'(z) at z = 1 + i.
message_2:
To find the derivative of f(z), we will first differentiate the real and imaginary parts of f(z) separately with respect to z. 

f(z) = 3z - i(z^2 - 3)
f(z) = 3z - iz^2 + 3i

Now, let's differentiate the real and imaginary parts separately:

Real part: 3z
Derivative of the real part: 3

Imaginary part: -iz^2 + 3i
Derivative of the imaginary part with respect to z: -i(2z)

Now, let's find the derivative of f(z) by combining the derivatives of the real and imaginary parts:

f'(z) = 3 - 2iz

Now, we will find the real and imaginary parts of f'(z) at z = 1 + i:

f'(1 + i) = 3 - 2i(1 + i)
f'(1 + i) = 3 - 2i - 2i^2
Since i^2 = -1,
f'(1 + i) = 3 - 2i + 2

The real part of f'(1 + i) is 3 + 2 = 5, and the imaginary part is -2i. So, the real and imaginary parts of f'(z) at z = 1 + i are 5 and -2i, respectively.
